AbstractText: The respiratory effects of O<sub>3</sub> are well established. High ambient O<sub>3</sub> concentrations are associated with respiratory symptoms, declines in pulmonary function, asthma exacerbations, and even mortality. The metabolic effects of O<sub>3</sub> are less well appreciated. Here we review data indicating that O<sub>3</sub> exposure leads to glucose intolerance and hyperlipidemia, characteristics of the metabolic syndrome. We also review the role of stress hormones in these events. We describe how the metabolic effects of O<sub>3</sub>, including effects within the lungs, are exacerbated in the setting of the metabolic derangements of obesity and we discuss epidemiological data indicating an association between ambient O<sub>3</sub> exposure and diabetes. We conclude by describing the role of the gut microbiome in the regulation of metabolism and by discussing data indicating a link between the gut microbiome and pulmonary responses to O<sub>3</sub>.
